case_vignette: A 7-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with swelling around her eye. This has happened to her before but has never been this severe. The lesion started a few days ago but has become increasingly red and painful. Physical exam reveals the lesion in Figure A which is tender to palpation. Her cranial nerves are intact and there is no pain with extraocular movements.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My eye is really swollen and it hurts more than it ever did before when this happened.
Is this swelling and pain located near your eyelid?
Yes, the swelling and pain are around my eye.
Have you noticed any redness or discharge from the eye?
It's gotten really red, but I don't have any goop coming out of it.
Have you recently injured your eye or had any trauma to the area?
No, I haven't hurt my eye or anything.

Have you taken any new medications recently?

**Final Diagnosis:** Allergic Conjunctivitis.

I. Periorbital Cellulitis or II. Orbital Cellulitis

Answer: II. Orbital Cellulitis.

This condition is a more serious form of periorbital cellulitis, which involves the infection spreading into the orbital tissue surrounding the eye. It requires prompt medical attention due to the potential for vision loss or other complications.
